text:
- Hi, I'm Kyliegh.
- And I'm Preston.

And we're from the series,
"Secrets of Sulphur Springs."

And we are psyched
to be here at Epcot,

and we're actually on our way to
"Remy's Ratatouille Adventure."
Let's go.

Kyliegh, come on.
We have to go.

We're going to
miss the attraction.

Preston was super eager
to get on the ride,

but I was too busy looking
at the French Pavilion.
I took so many pictures.

Kyliegh, hurry up.
Come on. Let's go.

I heard it's just like
being in the movie.

I just love Remy.
He's a little rat

that knows how to cook better
than everybody else.

In the beginning when you see
Chef Gusto, that was super cool

because he was actually
popping out at you,

and you could see
and hear him everywhere.

The food was huge.
It was like building-sized.

- Whoa!
- It feels like a giant orange,

like you could actually
pull it open,

and it'd be an actual orange.
And the details are amazing.
Whoa! This looks so real.

Living life as
a rat was very fun.

You could feel everyone
stomping around you,
like the ride will vibrate.

I loved it when we
slid under the stove

and the heat wave hit,
so it felt super real.
Oh! Hot!

I loved when we went
into the whole rat kitchen.

where Linguini was and all
the rats were just cooking.

- I thought it was so cute. 
- Oh, yeah.

It was super cool.
You had to dodge and turn

and twist in your cart,
like spin everywhere.

It was cool being
chased down by the chef.

Kyliegh: At one point you go
into the vents and it looks big
because you're a small rat.

The chef is chasing you,
and at one point,

he sticks his hand in,
and the wood just blows at you.
I got jump scared.

I love the cork blowing
up the bottle,
when your seat rumbled,

and then water
squirted all over you.

The attention to detail
was amazing.

The lighting. The sounds.
It was super cool.

- I think I need to go again.
- Five more times.
Five more times. Let's go.
Whoa!

Preston: So detailed!
So many details.
( laughing )
